The case against rent control:

Landlords have less incentive to build or maintain units if their profits are capped. There is no clear consensus among economists and housing experts on the long-term effects of rent control on affordability. Most agree that rent control provides short-term benefits to incumbent tenants but can have negative effects on the overall housing supply and quality.

Others maintain that rent control is counterproductive and that resources would be better spent on direct housing subsidies and increasing the overall housing supply.

In summary, while rent control provides immediate relief to tenants, its long-term effects on overall housing affordability are complex and depend on factors like the stringency of the policy, local housing market conditions, and complementary policies.
